docs.lead_paragraph: KLINE--Eugene M.,known to all as Gene, having survived just a few months past his 100th birthday, died quietly on the afternoon of Friday, October 10, 2014, at his home at Atria of Rye Brook. The cause was congestive heart failure, complicated by pneumonia. Always proud of his graduation from DeWitt Clinton High School, Eugene attended Columbia College, where he was coxswain and Phi Beta Kappa. He went on to Columbia Law School, from which he graduated in 1935 as a James Kent Scholar. Gene practiced law for just shy of 80 years, with a brief interruption for military service during World War II. On September 17, 2014, he forthrightly announced his retirement from the law firm of Phillips Nizer LLP, where he had practiced since 1943. He was the consummate lawyers' lawyer, frequently consulted by colleagues seeking technical advice about knotty legal issues. His dedication to the law was leavened by a lifelong love of jazz, art, the ballet, and the New York Football Giants. Gene was beloved as well as respected. He was married for 70 years to the artist Harriet Kline, who died in 2010. Though predeceased by his son Robert, Gene is survived by his granddaughter Lisa and by Robert's widow, Georgann Kline Ohsman. Gene is also survived by his son Thomas and grandchildren Andrew, Emily, and Daniel. Gene was laid to rest in a private ceremony on Sunday, October 12, 2014, at Mount Carmel Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made to the New York City Ballet, David H. Koch Theater, 20 Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023 or the Museum of Modern Art, 11 W 53rd St, New York, NY 10019.

docs.lead_paragraph: A classified review concluded that many past attempts by the agency to arm foreign forces covertly had a minimal impact on the long-term outcome of a conflict.
docs.snippet: A classified review concluded that many past attempts by the agency to arm foreign forces covertly had a minimal impact on the long-term outcome of a conflict....
docs.abstract: Central Intelligence Agency internal study finds that many past attempts by agency to arm foreign forces covertly had minimal impact on long-term outcome of a conflict; review shows that such efforts were even less effective when militias fought without any direct American support on the ground; findings lead to deep skepticism among Obama administration officials about wisdom of arming and training members of fractured Syrian opposition.

headline.print_headline: C.I.A. Study Says Arming Rebels Seldom Works
headline.main: C.I.A. Study of Covert Aid Fueled Skepticism About Helping Syrian Rebels

docs.abstract: Battery Conservancy, nonprofit that supports Battery Park, picks powder-coated steel chair by Andrew Jones Design as signature chair for park; chair, called Fleurt, wins over 679 entries from 15 countries; conservancy awards Jones $10,000 and will fabricate 300 chairs based on his design.
